DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: On the 100th anniversary of the Eiffel Tower, mock charges calculated to wound French pride claim the Parisian landmark was copied from an ordinary light tower in San Jose. The claim, a just-for-fun charge filed with San Jose's mock Court of Historical Inquiry, was brought against the estate of Alexandre Gustave Eiffel and demanded all profits the French have received since the 984-foot iron framework structure opened to sightseers at the Paris Exposition of 1889. The ``trial'' was set for Jan. 25. The complaint says Eiffel got his idea for the tower after being stricken dumb with admiration upon gazing at a now-defunct, 208-foot light tower at a San Jose intersection in 1881. The claim does not say what business Eiffel, an engineer, had in the orchard capital of Northern California. The claim will be prosecuted by Santa Clara County Deputy District Attorney Paul R. Bernal, who admitted his case was built on hearsay and not a hint of direct evidence. ``It was rumored at the time the light tower was built that Gustave Eiffel came to see it. ... We are going to substantiate that rumor,'' Bernal heatedly told reporters. Lawyer Jacques Dulin pledged to defend the French origin of the tower, describing the San Jose version as puny. ``We,'' he fumed, ``gave (the Americans) the Statue of Liberty. We did not give them the liberty to steal any of the other monuments of France.''

Mohair and cashmere are nice, but a weaver has another idea for your next sweater _ fido's fur. ``It's becoming very chic to have a scarf or sweater made from your own dog's hair,'' Kim Mikel, 28, said recently. Two years ago, Mikel turned her hobby of spinning yarn into a venture called Traditional Homespuns. She makes and sells such items as clothing and throw rugs. Mikel uses yarn made from the more than 30 Angora rabbits she and her husband, Jim, raise in their barn for scarves, sweaters and mittens. She also experiments with various combinations using Angora, sheep's wool, mohair, cotton yarns, and soon, dog hair. For her first experiment with dog hair, Mikel said, she will use fur from her pet Afghan, Oliver.
